title: Ideal Gas Proportions - Mixing two samples of gas

content.question: A sample of <math alttext="N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>N</mi></math> atoms of Gas <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is in a container with a piston that is free to move. The gas is at thermal equilibrium with its surroundings and has a volume of <math alttext="10 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mstyle></math>. A sample of <math alttext="2 N" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>2</mn><mi>N</mi></mstyle></math> atoms of Gas <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is added to the container. An atom of Gas <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has twice the mass of an atom of Gas <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. What is the volume of the mixture after the mixture has come to thermal equilibrium with the surroundings?
